captions.text:
Déjà vu is a phenomenon that all of us have
experienced, that eerie feeling when you walk

into a room or enter a new situation and you
say to yourself, "I've been here before. I
mean, everything here is familiar."

It turns out that we can actually induce forms
of déjà vu in subjects in experiments. So

there is a theory that says that déjà vu
simply elicits fragments of memories that

we have stored in our brain, memories that
can be elicited by moving into an environment

that resembles something that we've already
experienced. So we don't have to invoke parallel

universes, we don't have to invoke the multiverse
in order to explain most déjà vu.

However, it does raise the other question:
is it ever possible on any scale to perhaps

flip between different universes? And the
answer there is actually rather unclear. We

physicists believe, for example, that there
is really a multiverse that exists even inside

our living room. We are waves, vibrating waves
given by the **** function, and these waves
vibrate and then split apart with time.

Steve Weinberg, winner of the Nobel Prize,
compares it to the following. Think of radio.

If you're inside your living room listening
to BBC radio, that radio is tuned to one frequency.

But in your living room there are all frequencies
- radio Cuba, radio Moscow, the Top 40 rock

stations. All these radio frequencies are
vibrating inside your living room, but your
radio is only tuned to one frequency.

Now, in other words when two universes are
in phase, they are coherent and you can move

back and forth. But as time starts to evolve,
these two universes decouple. They start to

vibrate at different frequencies. They can
no longer interfere with each other. So why

is it that your radio cannot listen to Radio
Moscow? Why isn't it possible for your radio

to listen to all frequencies? Because your
radio is decohered. It is no longer vibrating
in unison with these other frequencies.

And the same thing in quantum physics. We
consist of atoms. Our atoms vibrate, but they

no longer vibrate in unison with these other
universes. We have decoupled from them, we

have decohered from them. So in other words,
deja vu is probably simply a fragment of our

brain eliciting memories and fragments of
previous situations. However, in quantum physics,

there really are in some sense parallel universes
surrounding us, the problem is, we can't enter

them because we have decohered from them.
We're no longer vibrating in unison with them.
Sorry about that.

title: Michio Kaku: What Is Déjà Vu?

I like this man, interesting, educational, charismatic and fascinating to 
listen !﻿

comments.text:
I think I have a case of reverse Deja Vu. Ever since I could remember, I 
would have a dream where I would be doing normal things, living my life 
through my own eyes: going to  school or eating breakfast etc. and would at 
some point later in time live the dream, so to speak. The things I saw, 
heard, and felt were exactly the way they were in my dream. Whenever it 
occurs I just let it happen, just to see if it will play out. But, String 
Theory, am I right? :p﻿

comments.author: isaiah Muse

comments.text:
i dont see it as a parallel universe thing,, its more like a signal message 
, a snap shot of information that is sent back through time to your brain 
in a supposed dream state, i believe that this information travels back in 
time because time flows backwards, we only perceive it as we do of going 
forward, also knowledge of the future can change it, which is the reason 
most of us do not remember the information received until it happens 
because if you change one thing the future changes and you will not arrive 
at that dejavu moment again thereby erasing the message that you sent, 
although the original message may be retained in the past as a dream 
experience﻿
comments.author: warlocksden

comments.text:
Ive gotten Deja Vu mutiple times and everytime i got it, i recognized that 
it was something i had experienced in another lifetime. It wasnt just a 
feeling of familiarity, it was an experience that was so precise so crystal 
clear, i knew it was more than my mind playing tricks on me. It was 
something greater... An external memory... Let me explain; An external 
memory is something that you experience in a life cycle that your mind has 
saved as a check point or as a message to ones own self, that you will 
recognize in the same life experience but in another moment in time. 
Bringing you to an alternate reality and sense of familiarity. To 
understand this, you have to first understand time and more importantly, 
life. Time has no beginning or end. "How is this relative to Deja Vu?" Its 
relative because the mind and the universe are one, traveling from 
experience to experience. Deja Vu is like forseeing the future, except the 
future doesnt exist because time doesnt actually exist. In reality, it just 
repeats. Its possible that through this infinite space and time, our lives 
repeat an infinite amount of times, and at any given moment your mind takes 
a snap shot of certain moments in a life cycle. This is what Deja Vu is. It 
has nothing to do with epilepsy.. Or schizophrenia... Or any other brain 
disorder. Its also possible that Deja Vu and destiny coexist. "How is this 
possible? And why?" You might ask... Well In external form the mind is in a 
state of perfection. Meaning we are in a state of perfect being. We know no 
greed, no pain, no fear, no emotions, no urges or sensations of the senses 
we gain from having a physical form. Because we arent in a physical form we 
are nothing but intelligence. Destiny would be described as our spiritual 
beings choosing a forseen path. Almost like a challenge of will power. We 
are all destined to be great. So we choose a predetermined path. But as we 
journey through a life experience in physical form we stray from our 
destined course. Maybe Deja Vu is a message to our physical being from our 
spiritual being, a message of/for good or bad, a message to relay ones own 
course of actions wether it is the right course or not. A checkpoint or a 
warning. See science can only explain so much. And its often innaccurate, 
and denotes the truth, persuading others to believe something false. When 
in fact, our thoughts are telling us the truth. The mind is a powerfull 
thing. You cant always rely on scientific explainations. 

For example, the "Big Bang Theory". Its simply just a theory. It denotes a 
universal intelligence or a higher power, stating that life is random. But 
if life began from cosmic gases, then ill simply ask, what created those 
gases? And if something created those gases, then again, ill ask, what 
created that?? same thing can be asked about "god". Who or what created 
god? And if so, what created that?? Theres always a new question to arise 
with every answer. The questions become infinite, as well as the answers 
do, until you reach the easiest explaination... Nothing. In the beginning 
there was nothing. Nothing but black, empty, darkness. But if life and all 
things began from nothing, than truly nothing is everything, because all 
things derived from nothing. This is how we know time is actually infinite, 
and if time is infinite than it is also irrelevant. Why? Because if time is 
infinite, life is infinite as well, and there is nothing to fear. The truth 
is life has no beginning or end. Yes our lives do...but that is the purpose 
of physicality. What we are experiencing in this moment is all we know. Its 
all we wanted to know, for a brief moment of infinity. This is the purpose 
of life, to experience. What is beyond this we only imagine. 

﻿
comments.author: Clinton T

comments.author: Pedro Martins

comments.author: TheLeast88

comments.text:
Typical. What about when people dream something, then it actually happens? 
 I guess "science" would call that person a "kook" or a "quack".  As he was 
babbling on about theoretical parallel universes and differing frequencies 
occupying the same space, and how it is a matter of tuning into them, he is 
lending credence to one of the principle embarrassments of science: the 
inability to explain how the brain generates consciousness.  It would be 
much more plausible to view the brain as a receiver of consciousness, as 
there is no scientific evidence to support the assumption that 
consciousness is generated by the brain...and no expense or effort has been 
spared in the process, much to its collective chagrin.

While there may be some truth to fragmented memories being seized upon by 
the brain to trigger the onset of deja vu, the "problem" isn't quite so 
simple.  Deja vu can be so undeniably visceral and pointed in one's 
experience (can't quantify, calculate, weigh, or measure it, sorry) that 
its reality is not to be denied.  That's a good thing, actually.  It tunes 
you in to the fact that this universe is infinitely mysterious, and our 
participation as humans is also mysterious.  Science is a wonderful 
invention of and by mankind to understand this universe, but it is limited 
in its applications due to its inherent utilitarian nature.  Phenomena such 
as deja vu clue us in to that very fact, and that is to be acknowledged and 
respected, as it presupposes the transcendence of time and space.  Some 
things are simply beyond rational explanation.﻿
comments.author: Celestial Scripture

comments.author: Jason Wong

comments.text:
I'm not attacking him because I admit he is much smarter than I am, but 
when people start quoting him as if his concepts are facts, that's when it 
ticks me off. I was sent here by a link from Facebook, claiming that deja 
vu `is' the result of parallel universes. No its not, it's already been 
established in psychology that deja vu is the result of a disturbance in 
our memory and perception. Chemistry is the reason, not our brain 
communicating with another self in another dimension.
comments.author: Jason Wong

comments.text:
Everyone just has to be able to tell the difference between claims and 
ideas.

Theoretical physics over time becomes 'real' physics. Not all of it, but 
some. Once upon a time anti-matter was theoretical.

The connection he suggests that may exist between the multiverse and 
deja-vu is not theoretical physics, it is philosophy at best. The 
multiverse itself is, yes. Not this. Theoretical physics is just the result 
of taking seriously theories that have been demonstrated to accurately 
describe reality, and seeing what come from it.
comments.author: Phynos

comments.text:
+Phynos and yet many people, some friends included, take his words as some 
kind of dogma, and keep perpetuating his hypotheses as facts. People should 
learn to distinguish between real physics and theoretical physics.
comments.author: Jason Wong

comments.text:
+Jason Wong That's right, he's only speculating and he never claims it is 
anything more than pure speculation.
comments.author: Phynos

comments.text:
What if deja-vu is a delay?
Maybe seeing / hearing something is one thing, being aware of it is 
another. Maybe becoming aware is like writing on disk, the brain fails to 
write, tries to write again from buffer being successful the 2nd time. 
That's when you're aware of the info, and some "frames" are already there 
from the 1st attempt. Maybe it writes again the part that it failed to 
write adding a fraction of a secon from before, like those split videos 
when part 2 starts with the last few seconds of part 1.﻿

comments.text:
So in theory, if parallel realities exist but on different frequencies, we 
have the ability to change our reality if we can master changing our own 
frequency, which in my opinion and in the teachings of a philosopher named 
Bashar (you can see Bashar videos on YouTube) you can do this by 
visualization and altering your thought patterns and belief systems to 
match the same frequency of the reality you desire. I can personally say 
that at some points in my life I have managed to tap in and out of parallel 
realities by tapping into an entirely different thought pattern and belief 
system and have witnessed real-time changes in my environment/interactions 
with other people. Example: if you visualize and change your belief system 
that the place you are walking is dangerous, you tap into a reality where 
actual dangers will suddenly manifest themselves as a part of your reality, 
because you are now on this frequency and subject to that particular 
reality, yet in the same exact environment you change your belief 
system/visualize that location being a safe oasis and all of a sudden, 
behold you are on this frequency and other things on this frequency/reality 
start manifesting themselves in real time (you hear children laughing/play, 
you encounter friendly people) - It's more than a matter of perception, 
thoughts have actual power to change physical reality in an obvious way. 
Almost every teaching/theory relating to this all has the same message but 
explained in a different way. From religious scholars, motivational 
speakers, now even physicists. If this theory be true, I believe *some* 
people that our society labeled mentally ill or those with hallucinations 
may in fact tapped into a reality or frequency where what they are 
experiencing/things they are seeing are part of a parallel dimension. In 
our eyes these people are crazy, but their experience, their existence, 
their thoughts, their visions are a *reality* for them, just because it is 
another reality from what we're experiencing doesn't make theirs any less 
valid or real from their personal experiences. ﻿
comments.author: Tom V

comments.text: holy shit i didn't understand anything ﻿
comments.author: Lord Voldemort

comments.text:
Kaku said that experiments can trigger deja vu by repeating events. To me 
that would just be a memory of the event. That doesn't explain how when I 
have deja vue everything is farmiliar. Everything!! Not just what was 
experience earlier. So that is not the whole story.
I have deja vu about once a month and sometimes more than once in the same 
day. But once it starts, no matter what I look at or think about or what 
people say, it all seems familiar.  I notice that during déjà vu I have 
slight disorientation, and/or slightly sleepwalking. (I know how it feels 
as I am waking up.) 
                        Here is my opinion on the "seen it before" theory, 
is that it would be too easy to prove if that were the case. They could 
create a very distinct object that nobody has seen before and see if they 
have deja vu about the object. Besides if seeing or experiencing things 
before would trigger it why would not we have deja vu all the time. Think 
about it a lot of the daily rituals like hygiene, grooming, dressing, 
cooking, eating, drinking, using the same words, same songs, same faces, 
etc. Most people rarely have deja vu.  In addition, if familiarity levels 
were a direct correlation to deja vu then wouldn't people who are limited 
in their senses like people what are blind and deaf have more deja vu since 
there life is so monotones?  If no difference was found then wouldn't that 
undermine the theory?  So let's throw that whole "seen all that before" 
theory out.
              I think the theory of the "eyes receiving info at different 
speeds" seems very unlikely. Surely, that would be easy to prove. Wouldn't 
virtual reality devices designed to simulate information reaching each eye 
at different speeds trigger deja vu if that were true?. Or what about 
analyzing the type of deja vu in people blind in one eye to make sure there 
is a commonality to weaken this theory.  So let’s place that theory in an 
inconvenient and faraway place.
                    The two theories that sound most plausible in my case 
are the "nerves out of whack" theory or the "different parts of the brain 
working on the same information at different speeds" theory. The most 
likely explanation I heard a while back is that the brain processes 
information twice. Nerves are involved in these two theories.
                           Deja vu has nothing to do with being psychic…If 
it did gamblers would simply wait until the have déjà vu and then place the 
bets…etc.(too easy to prove) Déjà vu has nothing to do with a apast life 
experience… Anyone old enough to have been born before brand new technology 
came out, like the computer for example, and has had deja vu about the 
computer, proves that it is not information from a past life since that 
information was not available before that person was born.  (There is no 
such thing as past lives anyway.)
The best and most satisfying explanation for deja vu is that it feels like 
a memory because one or more parts of your brain processed the information 
faster than another part(s).
 Check out my YouTube channel "Be a Nerd Monday". Sarcasm about bigfoot, 
aliens and other dry comedy about common subjects. (Sorry I am such a know 
it all. Hard to hold back something you know.)
Take care!﻿
comments.author: Be a Nerd Monday

comments.author: Alan Ranjoni

comments.text:
Deja Vu usually only occurs when the subject is tired / sleep deprived  or 
stressed (next time you have it , ask yourself if you are any of these) The 
brain in its tired state fails to process the input from the senses at its 
usual rate - it is, for a moment, a fraction of a second slow. Thus you get 
the sensation that something has happened before - once when you observed 
it and then again when the brain processes it that fraction of a second 
later. Its not a Matrix moment, its not previous lives or alternate 
universes -its just your brain rebooting for a fraction of a second.﻿
comments.author: Jon Snelgrove

like a radio with different radio stations ﻿

comments.text:
dejavu is memory.  memory can go forward and backward.  retrocognition and 
precognition.  life itself is a record.  each life cycle is a repeat, 
nothing is new.  there can be slight variations in each life cycle but the 
"big picture" never changes.  if you feel like you have been some place 
before, that is because you have been there before.  if you feel like what 
you're doing is something you have already done before, that is because you 
HAVE already done it.  i just made my eternal peanut butter oatmeal 
chocolate chip cookies last night.  and i did that because I ALWAYS BAKE 
THOSE COOKIES at that specific point in time.  and i am ALWAYS GOING TO 
BAKE THOSE COOKIES.  in my next life cycle (which is OUR life cycle) i am 
going to bake the very same eternal cookies, AND, i will be awake and aware 
and i will KNOW that they are eternal cookies ... because i am the same and 
i don't change.  i ALWAYS remember eternity, lol.﻿

comments.text:
Can I just say something? Please only use Michio Kaku and other 
"documentary" physicists as inspiration and introductions to a subject--do 
not take their analogies as fact, or as realistic representations of the 
mathematical models and sciences behind the theories. Upon questioning both 
my college physics professors regarding Michio Kaku's representations and 
analogies, they shook their heads and told me flat-out that what he's on 
about all the time is this sugar-coated, overly simplified version of 
physics.

So when Michio Kaku is openly declaring that time travel is possible, and 
multiverses are a fundamental doctrine of string theory, and that 
warp-holes could become reality in about a hundred years, or that he can 
theoretically build you a lightsaber--please keep in mind that in order for 
you to actually grasp what's going on here, you need about 8-9 years of 
physic. Advanced physics (often with heavy calculus and 
transcendental/linear algebra). If you don't have that, then please don't 
be an anus and crap over everyone about how science trumps all or that it 
has these magnificent properties or answers. Let's get real. 99% of the 
cow-brained atheists on this website couldn't tell their Gauss' Law from 
their Faraday Law, let alone Maxwell's equations. OR your religion. For 
Pete's sake please shut the f*** up about your religion. If you really 
believed in it enough you wouldn't be quibbling about it on YouTube.﻿
comments.author: Requiem

comments.text:
Okay so I saw some time travel explanations below and I just wanted to say 
that it makes sense but we don't know if the future is set in stone and 
we're on a path or if it depends on the choices we make. How can we be 
experiencing a check point if the future ISN'T set in stone? But maybe that 
just means the future isn't set in stone... who knows? 

I've experienced Deja Vu since I was a child, not that often tends to avg 
on abt 5 times a year. Probably a little less some years and a little more 
others. My earliest experience, that I remember, happened when I was 5 or 
6. It was very basic but I knew what I had experienced (or experienced 
again lol). I walked from my living room, over to my dinner table and 
looked up at the chandelier light fixture and that was it, I felt like I 
had already done it and was a little unnerved. To me Deja Vu was some scifi 
fantasy so it was def a weird thing to experience, the first known time.﻿

Greek Myth fake movies of the actual event of the slaughter of the 300; and

IS the media talking about the political, religious, traditional, war,

are children; who are later as adults, held into submission with laws to

(phrase is a Phrygian word); "don't kill the messenger" originates. The

comments.text:
When a life form experiences a change in climate, environment, food supply 
(as in an earthquake and volcanic dismantling of a land mass); the life 
form will have to modify it's life strategy to some degree. Needed to 
survive modifications of previous life strategies can result from things 
like volcanic eruptions, floods, earthquakes, tidal waves and tsunami's, 
asteroid strike, oil product related pollutions, fungus, virus, war, a 
nuclear bomb, a chemical spill, or other tramamtic event; but a forced on 
life modification is NOT the same as "evolution." If we have to "change" in 
order to survive, we either change or cease to exist.  Anyway, evolution 
has roots in a racist philosophy; as in the stronger resemblance of certain 
human race backgrounds to other life forms in what appears to be an string 
of related life forms; humans having the highest ability to use life 
energy, in the zones of our ability TO see what is really possible. What we 
DO see is to demonstrate TO US, humans; a small part of the power of the 
"something or someone or family of"  life forms we can not seem to see; and 
the power "the something life form" has over us, or that may not even 
exist. Do we really just turn into unusable dust?  In the wind? Is this 
highly complex frequency vibration all for the amusement of something that 
does not exist? Or is there "something else" we have to experience, with 
our human body that is somehow related to the life and body we will lose 
someday, in or at the end of this lifetime?  Science and math are valuable 
tools, religion is a crutch and an opiate, politics are a scam, the 
investment "industry" is a ponzi scheme, and people say it is going to "get 
worse."  Does that mean push button war or a savage door to door killing 
looting rampage?  We stopped evolving around 200,000 years ago, but we have 
modified our original survival and purpose strategies.  We have learned a 
little about flying in "Outer Space." The space program costs way too much 
for what it provides for most life forms. We have more important issues 
than building a "science shed" on Mars.  I agree with looking for and 
tracking asteroids, but "we" are way off track looking for resolutions to 
human made on Earth environmental problems on Mars, or floating in the 
atmosphere. Do you really have a real concept of how BIG it really is out 
there in "outer" space?   Way too big for my little head.   ﻿

comments.text:
Sorry but the explanation for Deja Vu is fairly simple and already known.

The biological one is that impulses get redirected to the long term memory 
first instead of directly to the short term memory.   Your experience on 
the moment seems to be exactly like the one in your memory. However, you 
can never remember where or when you've had this same experience before. 
The reason for that is because it is right on the same moment when the 
memory was created, there is no "before" from which you remember.

If it was parallel universes then everything would be affected and people 
have this over and over again. Right now it's  that a few people witness it 
somehow and often vaguely.﻿
comments.author: Nemo ΣΞ

comments.text:
I have a theory that Deja Vu might be a "check point" so to speak, for time 
travel. Like a "window of opportunity". It might not be actual "time 
travel" but could potentially be a way to carve a better path for yourself 
and change your own history. If you could predict deja vu, and actually act 
on whatever happens "next", but you're aware of the best possible outcome, 
then you could set a new path for yourself. Too bad no one's come up with a 
way to tap into these experiences yet.﻿
